target:
||startoftext||The patient is a 23-year-old male who presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain and nausea. He has a history of hypertension, diabetes type 2, and obesity. He was previously on medications such as metformin and lisinopril, but had not seen a primary care physician in a long time. He also uses cannabis regularly. 

The patient's symptoms included nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain, which improved with vomiting. He also reported constipation, but his last bowel movement was the morning of admission. 

The patient's physical examination was notable for acute distress and upper abdominal tenderness to palpation with hypoactive bowel sounds. Laboratory results showed a white blood cell count of 7.5 with 84% polymorphonuclear cells, hemoglobin of 13.5, and platelet count of 107. 

The patient underwent an endoscopy (EGD) which showed mild erythema in the antrum and moderate erythema and congestion in the stomach body. Biopsies were taken. 

The patient's diagnosis was not acute intra-abdominal process, but rather diffuse anasarca, hepatic steatosis, and borderline enlarged spleen. 

At discharge, the patient was prescribed medications including Famotidine, Acetaminophen, and Haloperidol. ||endoftext||
generated_summary: ||startoftext||The patient is a 24-year-old male with obesity, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and prior use of metformin and lisinopril. He presents with nausea/vomiting and abdominal pain that has worsened over several months. On examination, he appears alert and cooperates well. Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 7.5, hemoglobin of 14.6, and normal liver function tests and lipase levels. A gastroenterological endoscopy (EGD) revealed mild inflammation in the antrum and moderate erythema and congestion in the stomach-body region. The patient denies weight loss, fever, chills, and having experienced diarhea or bleeding stools. Instead, he experiences occasional mild headache. Treatment involved administering acetaminophen, lorazepam, famotidine, capsaicin, and antibiotics. Follow-up appointments included monitoring of blood glucose, lipid profiles, and organ function tests. ||endoftext||

3. Hepatic steatosis. 
4. Borderline enlarged spleen.

Discharge Instructions:
Instructions: Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure to be a part of your ___ team at ___ 
___.

====================================
Why did you come to the hospital? 
====================================

-You had abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting

====================================
What happened at the hospital? 
====================================

-You underwent upper endoscopy (EGD) test to look at the stomach 
area inside. The area looked normal. Biopsies were taken to look 
at tissue samples under a microscope. The results will take days 
to come back. Your new GI doctor ___ inform you of the results.
-The abdominal pain explanation is still unclear at time of 
discharge. The biopsy results are key to understanding if you 
may have a recurrent H pylori infection or not, as the possible 
cause of your pain.

==================================================
What needs to happen when you leave the hospital? 
==================================================

-For the abdominal pain: You will trial an acid reducing pill 
(pantoprazole) for 6 weeks as prescribed. Eat small regular 
meals and take anti-nausea meds as needed.

-Please set up a follow up appointment with your PCP and GI 
doctor as instructed. 

-You must see your PCP to have ___ referral to a kidney specialist 
(nephrologist) because of your high blood pressure at such a 
young age and that can be damaging your kidneys slowly over 
time.

-You must see your PCP to have ___ referral to a cardiologist, as 
there was evidence of heart disease based on bloodwork and the 
CT scan you had. This is absolutely important for you to get 
this investigated further in the office.

-For your diabetes: You need to take metformin to keep your 
blood sugars controlled

It was a pleasure taking ___ of you during your stay! 

Sincerely, 

Your ___ team  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 7.5, hemoglobin of 14.6, and normal liver function tests and lipase levels. A gastroenterological endoscopy (EGD) revealed mild inflammation in the antrum and moderate erythema and congestion in the stomach-body region. The patient denies weight loss, fever, chills, and having experienced diarhea or bleeding stools. Instead, he experiences occasional mild headache. Follow-up appointments included monitoring of blood glucose, lipid profiles, and organ function tests. ||endoftext||

target:
||startoftext||The patient is a 74-year-old female who was admitted with a chief complaint of ischemic bowel. She has a history of scleroderma, gastric dysmotility, and chronic parenteral nutrition. She was transferred from another hospital after presenting with fevers and chills, and was found to be hypotensive upon arrival. She required aggressive volume resuscitation and pressor support to maintain a systolic blood pressure above 90. Her ostomy output was bloody, and she reported not feeling well and having fevers and chills.

The patient underwent several surgeries, including an extended right colectomy, cholecystectomy, and ileostomy. She also had a right hepatic laceration treated with argon beam coagulation and packing. She was found to have extensive circumferential bowel wall thickening on CT scan, which was highly concerning for ischemic bowel.

The patient's diagnosis was ischemic bowel, and she was also diagnosed with sepsis. She was treated with antibiotics and pressor support, and her white count normalized. She was discharged to a rehabilitation facility with a tracheostomy, gastrostomy, and ileostomy, and was instructed to follow up with her doctor and to resume her regular medications.

The patient's medications at discharge included insulin, miconazole, lansoprazole, pregabalin, escitalopram, levothyroxine, metoprolol, and heparin. She was also instructed to follow up with lab work and to add fat back to her TPN when her liver enzymes trended down. ||endoftext||
generated_summary: startoftext||The patient is a 74-year-old female who underwent several surgeries at a hospital, including an extended right colectomy, treatment of a right hepatic laceration with an argon beam coagulation, closure of a rectus abdominis muscle opening, reopening of the abdomen, and removal of a Port-A-Cath device. She also experienced bleeding from an abdominal stoma and was diagnosed with gastrouductal obstruction syndrome, necessitating a gastostomy procedure. Additionally, she was prescribed various medications during her hospital stay, including insulin, miconazole nitrate, lanoprazole, pregabalin, escitalopram, levothyroxine, metoprolol tartrate, heparin, outpatient lab work, and TPN. At discharge, she was advised to monitor her weight closely and report any changes in her symptoms to her healthcare provider. ||endoftext||

Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
have any of the following:
 
 * You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
 tightness.
 
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
 medications.
 
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
 diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
 mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
 
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
 bowel movement.
 

* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
 degrees or 38(C) degrees.

target: ||startoftext||The patient is a 74-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for artherosclerosis with rest pain following a left femoral to posterior tibial bypass with in-situ greater saphenous vein. She has a history of diabetes, lower back pain with radiculopathy, and Achilles tendon rupture. The patient has allergies to penicillins and Duragesic. She underwent a major surgical procedure, a left femoral to posterior tibial bypass with in-situ GSV, and tolerated it well. At discharge, the patient was prescribed medications including acetaminophen, aspirin, docusate sodium, duloxetine, ezetimibe, pravastatin, metoprolol, and pregabalin. The patient was discharged home with service and instructed to follow up with the office for any concerns. ||endoftext||
generated_summary:
||startoftext||The patient is a 74-year-old female who was admitted for surgical procedures including a coronary artery bypass grafting and an in-studied great saphenous vein resection. She had a history of diabetic nephropathy, lower back pain, Achilles tendon rupture, and peripheral Vascular Disease. At the time of admission, she presented with symptoms of rest pain in both legs following previous treatments for these conditions. The patient's past medical history includes diabetes, lower back pain, achilles tendon rupture, and peritoneal cancer treatment. She has allergies to penicillins/Duressics.

During hospital stay, the patient underwent general anesthesia, endotracheal intubation, and received medications such as duloxetine, zetia, Novolog Sliding Scale, Lantus, metoprolol, Percecote prn, pravastatin, pregabaline, aspirin, docusate sodium, ezetimibe, oxycodone, and polyethylene glycol. She experienced significant discomfort during surgery but did not require any additional interventions beyond the initial procedure.

At discharge, the patient reported being able to ambulate around her home, although advised against bearing excessive weight on her feet initially. Her medications include acetaminophen, aspirin, duloxetine, ezetimibe, and others prescribed for various conditions, including osteoarthritis and hypertension. ||endoftext||

At the time of admission, she presented with symptoms of rest pain in both legs following previous treatments for these conditions. The patient's past medical history includes diabetes, lower back pain, achilles tendon rupture, and peritoneal cancer treatment. She has allergies to penicillins/Duressics.

During hospital stay, the patient underwent general anesthesia, endotracheal intubation, and received medications such as duloxetine, zetia, Novolog Sliding Scale, Lantus, metoprolol, Percecote prn, pravastatin, pregabaline, aspirin, docusate sodium, ezetimibe, oxycodone, and polyethylene glycol. She experienced significant discomfort during surgery but did not require any additional interventions beyond the initial procedure.

At discharge, the patient reported being able to ambulate around her home, although advised against bearing excessive weight on her feet initially. Her medications include acetaminophen, aspirin, duloxetine, ezetimibe, and others prescribed for various conditions, including osteoarthritis and hypertension. ||endoftext||

target:
||startoftext||The patient is a 65-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with shortness of breath. She has a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease, peripheral artery disease, and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) on hemodialysis three times a week. She also has diabetes mellitus, type 2, and hyperlipidemia. The patient's past medical history includes a left stent placement, coronary artery disease, and a hysterectomy. She has allergies to Motrin and has a family history of diabetes and hypertension.

The patient's presenting symptoms included shortness of breath, which began at 5 a.m. that morning. She had no associated chest pain, nausea, diaphoresis, dizziness, or lightheadedness. Her vital signs upon admission were normal, and she was treated with aspirin and admitted directly to dialysis.

The patient's diagnosis was acute on chronic diastolic heart failure, ESRD on HD, hypertensive urgency, and urinary tract infection. She was treated with hemodialysis, her usual blood pressure medications, and antibiotics for her urinary tract infection. She was also prescribed a sliding scale of insulin to cover her diabetes.

The patient's medications at discharge included amiodarone, calcium acetate, clonidine, epoetin alfa, furosemide, isosorbide mononitrate, lidocaine, lisinopril, metoprolol tartrate, simvastatin, and acetaminophen. ||endoftext||

rightward mass effect and resolved effacement of frontal horns 
after resection 
of previously seen large left frontal mass.

Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted from the emergency room to the neurosurgery 
service on ___. He was started on decadron and cont on his 
Keppra. He underwent a CTA to evaluate the vasculature around 
the mass and a WAND MRI for intra op guidance. 
On ___ he was taken to the operating room and underwent a left 
frontal craniotomy and tumor resection. Post operatively he was 
admitted to the ICU for close neurological monitoring and strict 
blood pressure control. On post op exam he was doing well. He 
was AOx3, following commands, his speech was intact and he moved 
all ext with ___ strength. He did have a post operative head ct 
that showed no new hemorrhage and good resection of tumor. 
 On ___ pt was transfered to the floor in stable condition. He 
was mobilized OOB and his foley catheter was removed. He had no 
trouble voiding on his own or tolerating a PO diet. On ___ & 
___ He remained neurologicaly intact and was seen by the 
physical therapists who cleared him for discharge home. His 
decadron was started on a wean.
On ___ the patient felt comfortable ambulating independently 
and was without complaint. He was discharged home.

chemotherapy meds, decadron, morphine, protonix, keppra

Discharge Instructions:
GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS
WOUND CARE:
You or a family member should inspect your wound every day and 
report any of the following problems to your physician. 
Keep your incision clean and dry.
You may wash your hair with a mild shampoo 24 hours after your 
sutures are removed.
Do NOT apply any lotions, ointments or other products to your 
incision.   
DO NOT DRIVE until you are seen at the first follow up 
appointment.
Do not lift objects over 10 pounds until approved by your 
physician.

DIET
Usually no special diet is prescribed after a craniotomy. A 
normal well balanced diet is recommended for recovery, and you 
should resume any specially prescribed diet you were eating 
before your surgery.  Be sure however, to remain well hydrated, 
and increase your consumption of fiber, as pain medications may 
cause constipation. 

MEDICATIONS:
Take all of your medications as ordered.  You do not have to 
take pain medication unless it is needed.  It is important that 
you are able to cough, breathe deeply, and is comfortable enough 
to walk.   
Do not use alcohol while taking pain medication. 
Medications that may be prescribed include: 
oNarcotic pain medication such as Dilaudid (hydromorphone).  
oAn over the counter stool softener for constipation (Colace or 
Docusate). If you become constipated, try products such as 
Dulcolax, Milk of Magnesia, first, and then Magnesium Citrate or 
Fleets enema if needed). Often times, pain medication and 
anesthesia can cause constipation.
If you have been prescribed Dilantin (Phenytoin) for 
anti-seizure medicine, take it as prescribed and follow up with 
laboratory blood drawing in one week.  This can be drawn at your 
PCPs office, but please have the results faxed to ___. 
If you have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam), you will 
not require blood work monitoring.
If you were on a medication such as Coumadin (Warfarin), or 
Plavix (clopidogrel), or Aspirin, prior to your surgery, you 
should not resume taking this until cleared by your doctor.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc, as this can increase your chances of bleeding. 
If you are being sent home on steroid medication, make sure 
you are taking a medication to protect your stomach (Prilosec, 
Protonix, or Pepcid), as these medications can cause stomach 
irritation.  Make sure to take your steroid medication with 
meals, or a glass of milk. 

ACTIVITY:
The first few weeks after you are discharged you may feel tired 
or fatigued. This is normal. You should become a little stronger 
every day. Activity is the most important measure you can take 
to prevent complications and to begin to feel like yourself 
again. In general:
Follow the activity instructions given to you by your doctor 
and therapist.
Increase your activity slowly; do not do too much because you 
are feeling good.
You may resume sexual activity as your tolerance allows.
If you feel light headed or fatigued after increasing 
activity, rest, decrease the amount of activity that you do, and 
begin building your tolerance to activity more slowly.
DO NOT DRIVE until you speak with your physician.
Do not lift objects over 10 pounds until approved by your 
physician.
Avoid any activity that causes you to hold your breath and 
push, for example weight lifting, lifting or moving heavy 
objects, or straining at stool.
Do your breathing exercises every two hours.  
Use your incentive spirometer 10 times every hour,  that you 
are awake.
